answers.explanation:
The OCT demonstrates loss of the neurosensory retina (green arrow), RPE (blue arrow) and choroid (red arrow) corresponding to the retinal lesion seen on fundus examination. There is no subretinal fluid or sign of choroidal neovascularization. Focal choroidal excavation presents with an intact overlying neurosensory retina and a concavity of the underlying choroid.

![](/content/media/paed_7_4.webp)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the main finding in the OCT above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Based on the exam findings and OCT imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Ocular toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of infectious retinochoroiditis in humans. This disease is due to infection by Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular parasite who’s obligate host is cats. Transmission is through fecal-oral route. Toxoplasmosis most commonly presents as necrotizing retinitis and vasculitis. The classic finding on exam is focal white retinitis with overlying inflammation, or a “headlight in the fog” with an adjacent pigmented retinochoroidal scar. Other ocular findings include iridocyclitis, vitreous inflammation, and ocular hypertension. Due to the high prevalence of toxoplasmosis infection in the population, a lack of IgG positive serology for T. gondii can rule out infection, but positive titers are not used for diagnosis. However, T. gondii PCR from aqueous or vitreous fluid has recently been demonstrated to have high sensitivity and specificity for disease.

​

References:

Kim SJ, Scott IU, Brown GC, et al. Interventions for toxoplasma retinochoroiditis: a report by the American Academy of Ophthalmology. Ophthalmology 2013;120(2):371-8.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on the patient age and ocular exam, is this considered congenital ocular toxoplasmosis?

answers.explanation:
Congenital toxoplasmosis infection can occur through transplacental transfer from mother to fetus, with clinical manifestations largely dependent on the age of the fetus during infection. This patient most likely does not have congenital toxoplasmosis, as congenital infection typically leads to neurological deficits and disability, as well as other ocular manifestations including microphthalmia, optic nerve atrophy and cataract. Toxoplasmosis is part of the “TORCH” congenital infections, which include syphilis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes viruses.

References:

Singh S. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Clinical features, outcomes, treatment, and prevention. Trop Parasitol 2016;6(2):113-122.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
After consultation with Infectious Disease, the patient was diagnosed with ocular toxoplasmosis and treated with Double Strength (DS) Septra (sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim) for 6 weeks. The presence of bilateral retinal scars with active chorioretinitis and vitritis suggested reactivation of latent infection, confirmed with positive serology.

However, 1 year later, the patient returned with redness, pain, and decreased vision in the left eye. Her visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/40 OS. IOP was 18 OD and 38 OS. There was no RAPD. Fundus photos were taken at this visit and are shown below:

![](/content/media/paed_7_5.webp)

![](/content/media/paed_7_6.webp)

An OCT over the lesion in the left eye was taken and is shown below:

![](/content/media/paed_7_7.webp)

What is the main finding in the OCT above?

answers.explanation:
The OCT shows hyper-reflectivity of the neurosensory retina with associated thickening (blue arrow) and choroidal hyporeflectivity and thickening. You can also appreciate the overlying vitreous cells (green arrow) and partial posterior vitreous detachment (red arrow) over the toxoplasmosis lesion.

![](/content/media/paed_7_8.webp)

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text:
Fundus examination demonstrated the hallmark “headlight in a fog” lesion, with the white focal retinitis adjacent to an old toxoplasmosis chorioretinal scar and overlying vitritis, as well as diffuse vasculitis. The patient was diagnosed with recurrent toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis and associated hypertensive uveitis.

What is the classic treatment for ocular toxoplasmosis?

answers.answerText: A. Triple therapy of pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, prednisone and folinic acid
answers.explanation:
The American Uveitis Society cited that triple therapy with pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine and folinic acid +/- corticosteroids is the treatment of choice for ocular toxoplasmosis. Folinic acid (leucovorin) is used as pyrimethamine is a folic acid antagonist. Our patient was also started on topical steroids and 3 topical anti-hypertensive classes of medication to control her intraocular pressure.

References:

Holland GN, Lewis KG. An update on current practices in the management of ocular toxoplasmosis. Am J Ophthalmol 2002;134(1):102–14.

title: Case 7
description: 12F presenting with pain and decreased vision OD
patientPresentation:
A 12-year-old girl presented to a paediatric eye clinic with pain, redness, photophobia and decreased vision of the right eye. She denied trauma, recent travel, or sick contacts. She had no past ocular or medical history. She was on no medications. Visual acuity was 20/50 OD and 20/20 OS. There was no RAPD. IOP was 10 mmHg OD and 12 mmHg OS. Anterior segment exam revealed 1+ conjunctival injection with granulomatous keratic precipitates inferiorly, 4+ cells, focal posterior synechiae, a clear lens and 1+ vitreous cells in the right eye. The left eye anterior segment examination was unremarkable. Her optic nerves and macula were normal. Fundus photography was taken and is shown below:

![](/content/media/paed_7_1.webp)

![](/content/media/paed_7_2.webp)

A superonasal hyperpigmented chorioretinal scar with an adjacent white retinal lesion at the border was found in the right eye (not imaged). There was associated vitritis. The left eye also demonstrated a hyperpigmented chorioretinal scar superior to the optic nerve.
